summary: Navigation on hikes is no longer a problem. Download the map, put notes and go!
changelog:
• Widgets redesign: new Look &  Feel, group by Pages, change order and combine as you want.
• Hiking / Cycling / Travel routes: tap on the route symbol and get full information about the route.
• Favorite groups: set default appearance for new points in the group
• Fixes: online tile-maps auto-update

reviews.review: I've bought and tried all the big name map applications and not one brings enough for me to change so far. I will always look for one thats better. I almost changed to Rever last year just because of the trail playback feature but that just didn't overcome deficiencies in other areas. 3000 miles Canada to Mexico on dirtbike trails with zero issues. Alpine loop, perfect. GPX planning, a caveman can do it. Used it daily for 5 years on my job and is my go to for off grid (satellite only) navigation

Once I find an address it works really well, I have found the search frustrating. It often cannot find an address, or finds the road but not the house number. Many time I have entered the while address and it has no reasonable suggestions.

reviews.review: The App itself is great. It has whole ton of Feautres, that do make the App appear a little bit convoluted in the Settings, but I'm glad they are there for those who need it. Other then that, it does what it is supposed to do, and it does it quite well. However: This is Open Street Maps. Which has upsides: Community Based, open Source, your Data won't be collected from Vultures as Google. The Downside: House Numbers might be an Issue in Rural Ares. The smaller the Place, the higher your Chances that OSM will know the Street, but no Numbers. If your are around more often in those Rural areas, because eg you are a Delivery Driver, you are propably better off with a non Open Navigation. To be fair tough: The bigger the City, the more likely it is, that the Maps are supar. In my current 100k City I am proud to say, that OSM beats Google without any Issues.

reviews.review: Really good app. I use it often on the motorbike for turn-by-turn navigation. The openstreetmap maps are much more informative then google maps, and osmand is incredibly flexible for you to change the look of the maps and what information is displayed. Also really awesome that you can get very frequent updates, so if you (or someone else) updates Openstreetmap, you can even get the updates live. I use OsmAnd for about 6 years. This is the most serious issue I face, regarding the app use I do. There are a lot of issues in the OsmAnd user interface but let's keep the story short. So after every second or third app update, the data folder location is changed or the user external accessibility to this folder is changed. I think that the excuse by the developers is that the Android updates are the ones to be blamed. The last achievement now is that there is not any way for the user to manage or to get the archived gps recordings through a direct connection (i.e. usb), they are hidden no matter what "type of storage" the user opted for in the app. The only ways are either to manage in app each file individually with limited options, one file at a time, or to "export" them through the app, where the export target option is only to some other apps or to the cloud, again one file at a time! So far I have about 400 to 500 gps recordings archived in the OsmAnd data folder!
reviews.reply:
Hello!
You can select "External data storage" to have direct access to your files. You can also install file managers for example File Commander or Solid Explorer, they appear in the share sheet and allow to save files from OsmAnd to the needed folder on the device.
If it doesn't help, please contact us at support@osmand.net

The last update is a blessing. Routing that finally works (and the online routing options are great as well as they're fast). Sure the UI isn't as polished as the likes of google but I'm happy about it as long as I can configure it and no engine is deciding what to show me based on some corporations monetisation drive... I was using OsmAnd for quite a while mostly when walking/touring just to see the map (as the data is greatly detailed down to local footpaths, dirt tracks and secret places) but the last update made even car navigation possible again. Oh and I also use it to navigate on a motorcycle by importing .gpx generated elsewhere (QMapShack) but the functional routing will make that much easier now as well. Happy. Please continue the development of routing algorithms (having a possibility of visual choice between "fastest"/"shortest" route would be lovely - like how Here maps had it in the past) and I'll be your happy subscriber.

I think you have nice and complete details on your map and it's really wonderful that everything works well offline. my only problem is that I need contours for my hiking and I'm living in a country which I can't pay for that. so apart from that everything is very good

Aplikaci bych rád používal na turistiku a cyklistiku. Hodnocení z tohoto pohledu: + podrobnost map mi vyhovuje, obecně se mi líbí myšlenka OpenStreetMap + ovládání i prostředí je dobré, spousta věcí se dá nastavit, což mám rád - chybí mi možnost vlastního nastavení barev pro jednotlivé cesty. Takto ať si vyberu jaký chci styl mapy, pro turistiku a cyklistiku je to vždy mírně nepřehledné, ale asi bych si zvykl - plánování tras je jednoduché a funguje dobře až na jednu, pro mě ale zásadní věc - vypočtený čas na trasu funguje asi jen pro pěší, pro ostatní je úplně špatně, např. trasa po silnici 3,6km - automobil 39min, kolo 40minut, pěší 54min. Přitom, stejnou trasu OsmAnd při prosté navigaci spočítá správně 4min/19min/52min. - hlasová navigace po předem naplánované trase je hrozná, často hlásí odbočky způsobené zakřivením cesty, navíc pokud jsou dvě odbočky blízko za sebou, na první odbočce už hlásí odbočku další, což je velice nepříjemné (telefon při jízdě na kole mám většinou v kapse). Při obyčejné navigaci z bodu A do bodu B mi přišlo, že hlasové pokyny fungují dobře.

Really great app, it has so many features & has evolved well over the years. I find it handy for planning & following routes. Sad to say there is a problem which lets it down badly. Usually, when you enter a destination & expect to be presented with a reasonably useful route think again. What you will most likely be presented with is a route that will wind & zigzag across the map no matter what parameters you enter. To get anywhere I end up breaking the route into short sections that follow the route I really want to use. Of course the problem with this approach is the need to stop at the end of each section to select the next leg, hardly ideal! Even using this method, on numerous occasions while following along an A or B road I get directions to turn into a cresent which then rejoins the road only a matter of meters on ahead. Often it's obvious I need to ignore these silly detours but they're distracting all the same. Conclusion, I still love the app which deserves 5 stars anyway, but can it be that difficult to improve the routing algorithm?

This is the most frustrating app I use. It has the world's worst user interface, there are so many options jumbled all over the place and it keeps changing. I create a GPX and want to follow it as is. If I wander off, I want to know. In the latest version I just cannot find how to switch off navigation between waymarks. For some reason it thinks the best route is usually a complex roundabout route whereas the path I've plotted with the official definitive mapped rights of way may be straight on (I use OS maps in the UK). It also announces EVERY waymark with "you have reached your intermediate destination". If I've used Google to help create the road sections of my routes then this can be every 100m/yds. This creates so much spoken chaff it is then hard to identify the genuine changes of direction. I've looked for documentation, but the website is full of feature-fluff with no details of how to use it in practice. At the moment I don't use the follow-track navigation with voice announcements as it has become unusable. I keep the screen on and look where the route goes. Not ideal for a short ride and hopeless for a longer one due to battery life. However once set-up it works really well and I've used it, screen off with voice announcements for exploring local byways and several multi-day treks. When working, the voice announcements are great, they count down to give plenty of warning and allow you to look out for the finger-post or road junction. In comparison Google navigation doesn't do the countdown anywhere near as well. I've used this app for several years and been a sub for 2. If I cannot figure out the latest version I'll be cancelling my renewal and looking for something whose features I can actually work.

Though it takes a while to learn how it all works, OsmAnd is a powerful navigation tool. Once you optimize each preset, like one for hiking and one for driving, it's easy to switch dozens of settings easily. So your driving preset can have a simple road map that orients the map to your direction of travel, while the hiking preset can have topo and satellite overlays (simultaneously!) and bearing readout without map rotation. And all of this can be set up for offline use, which is wonderful

description:
Features:
- Month view.
- Week, day & agenda view.
- Uses Android calendar sync. Works with Google Calendar, Exchange..etc.
- Material design.
- Dark & Light Theme.
- Offline Calendar
- Free, open source and absolutely no Ads.
- Support sharing calendars via ics and the ability to import/export from sdcard.
 
Bugs & feedback: https://github.com/Etar-Group/Etar-Calendar/issues
Source Code: https://github.com/Etar-Group/Etar-Calendar
summary: Etar is a material designed open source calendar, for everyone!
changelog:
- General bug fixes
- New translations.
- Add DecSync and Birthday Adapter to "known" apps and don't crash
- Fix crash and notifications on Android 12
- Fix MIME type of shared event.
